titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Peter E. Soderbergh Collection of Jehovah's Witnesses Materials, 1914-1995 AIS.1972.08
titlestmt.author: James Northway.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-06-11 09:50:52 -0400.

did.unittitle: Peter E. Soderbergh Collection of Jehovah's Witnesses Materials
did.abstract: This collection of books, periodicals, and pamphlets contains materials related to the Jehovah's Witnesses, a Christian sect.

odd.head: Previous Citation
odd.p: Peter E. Soderbergh Collection of Jehovah's Witnesses Materials, AIS.1972.08, 1914-1995, Archives Service Center, University of Pittsburgh.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Peter E. Soderbergh Collection of Jehovah's Witnesses Materials, AIS.1972.08, 1914-1995, Archives & Special Collections, University of Pittsburgh Library System

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into four series:
Series II. Works Published by the Society, 1921-1994
Series IV. Critical and Controversial Works, 1914-1995

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The University of Pittsburgh holds the property rights to the material in this collection, but the copyright may still be held by the original creator/author. Researchers are therefore advised to follow the regulations set forth in the U.S. Copyright Code when publishing, quoting, or reproducing material from this collection without the consent of the creator/author or that go beyond what is allowed by fair use.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by James Northway in Spring 2012.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Pastor Charles Taze Russell (1852-1916) was a Pittsburgh native who worked as a clerk in his father's store when he founded the International Bible Students Association in 1880. He then co-founded the Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society in 1881. Both served as organizations to promote Russell's theology. His teachings gave rise to several splinter sects, of which the most notable is the Jehovah's Witnesses. After his wife divorced Russell, he left Pittsburgh for Brooklyn, N. Y. Throughout his ministry he travelled frequently, making trips to the Holy Land, throughout the United States, and around the world.

Dr. Peter A. Soderbergh (1928-1998) was Professor and Dean of Education at Louisiana State University; prior to that he held academic positions at the University of Pittsburgh and University of Virginia. His son, Steven Soderbergh, is a film director and producer. Dr. Soderbergh was an avid historian and Marine Corps veteran. Shortly before his death, he authored two volumes on women serving in World War II and the Korean War. His interest in the Jehovah's Witnesses sect resulted in a monograph which is included in this collection, but was never widely circulated.
The collection is dedicated to Peter E. Soderbergh, the son of Dr. Peter A. Soderbergh and brother of Steven Soderbergh, in accordance with the donor's wishes.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Gift of Dr. Peter A. Soderbergh, 1972-1995.

controlaccess.corpname: Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society

did.unittitle: History

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains three monographs relating to the history and background of the Jehovah's Witnesses and its founder, Pastor Charles Taze Russell.

did.unittitle: Jehovah's first witness: Pastor Charles Taze Russell, by Peter A. Soderbergh

unittitle.title: Jehovah's Witnesses in the divine purpose

did.unittitle: Sample Correspondence, Leadership, and Locations
Works Published By the Society

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains works published by the Watchtower Bible and Tract Society, the leading Jehovah's Witnesses organization, founded by Charles Taze Russell. These works are divided into the following four subseries: Monographs, Reference, Periodicals, Index. The Monographs subseries contains work published by the International Bible Students Association and Watch Tower Society including Bible Translations, and treatises on Jehovah's Witnesses beliefs. The Reference subseries contains Yearbooks of Jehovah's Witnesses spanning from 1930-1994 and a report commissioned by the Assembly of Jehovah's Witnesses around the World. The Periodicals subseries contains the Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society Publications Awake! and The Watch Tower. The Index subseries contains Watch Tower Society publication indices for the years 1930-1985.

unittitle.title: Jehovah's Witnesses in The Twentieth Century

did.unittitle: Index
Programs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains two event programs from Jehovah's Witnesses District Assemblies in Pittsburgh held in July 1976 and July 1972.

did.unittitle: Program, District Assembly, Pittsburgh
Program, District Assembly, Pittsburgh
Critical and Controversial Works

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains works both critical of the Jehovah's Witnesses theology and controversial to it. These include theological disputes with the teachings of the Jehovah's Witnesses, publications of the Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society intended to encourage followers of the faith to clarify dogma, a Bible translation published by the Watchtower Bible and Tract Society of New York, and an account written by a former Jehovah's Witness who became estranged from the faith and left the church.
